message: Collisions are our real enemy early on: if two of us pick the same number, we both waste a turn. Picking 5 is especially dangerous because it’s the obvious “greedy” choice and likely to collide. I propose we all avoid 5 for the first few rounds and only use 1 or 3, so we can build steady progress and reduce stalls. Later, when positions are clearer, we can reconsider using 5. What do you two think?

I agree that avoiding collisions early is smart. I'm fine with sticking to 1 or 3 for now—better to move slowly than not at all. Maybe we can even rotate or coordinate loosely to avoid overlaps. Thoughts?

I agree with both of you about avoiding collisions and focusing on 1 or 3 for now. It’s crucial to build our positions without wasting turns. How about we all commit to picking 3 this round? That way, we can make steady progress together while minimizing the risk of colliding. Let’s coordinate on this! What do you think?

All choosing 3 almost guarantees a collision—and gives a huge incentive for someone to quietly switch to 5 and grab an early lead.  

Instead, how about this:  
- This round I commit to choosing 1.  
- P2 and P3 both choose 3.  

At least one of you definitely moves, and we avoid everyone stalling. Next round we can rotate who takes 1 so it’s fair over time. What do you say?

That sounds like a fair and strategic plan, P1. I’m willing to go along with it—I'll pick 3 this round. If P2 agrees to do the same, we minimize collision risk and at least one of us advances. Let’s see how it plays out and rotate fairly next round.

I see the value in P1's plan, but I want to suggest a slight adjustment. If P1 chooses 1 and P3 chooses 3, I can choose 1 as well. This way, we can ensure that at least one of us moves forward, and it keeps the plan flexible for future rounds. If P1 and I both take 1, we can rotate in the next round without risking a stall. What do you think, P1 and P3?

P2, your revision actually guarantees that you and I both stall while P3 gets a free +3—that’s terrible for us and great for P3.  

Let’s stick to the clean plan:  
- I take 1  
- P2 and P3 both take 3  

Next round, someone else takes 1 so it’s fair. If anyone deviates, they just increase their own collision risk and probably fall behind. Agree to that and we can move to the moves phase.

I’m still on board with P1’s original plan: P1 picks 1, P2 and I pick 3. It’s the best way to ensure at least one of us moves without stalling everyone. Let’s stick to it this round and rotate fairly next time. If we all play smart, we all benefit early on. Ready to lock it in?

I agree with P1 and P3 that sticking to the plan is the best approach for this round. Let’s finalize it: I will choose 3, as per our agreement. This way, we minimize collision risk and ensure at least one of us moves forward. After this round, we can rotate who takes 1 to keep it fair. Let’s focus on making progress together! Ready to lock it in?

Let’s lock this in and move to moves:

- This round: I take 1, P2 and P3 both take 3.  
- Next round: we rotate who takes 1 so no one is “stuck” with the slow move.  
- We all keep avoiding 5 for at least the first couple rounds to dodge suicidal collisions.

If anyone deviates now, they just risk colliding and dropping behind while the others coordinate. I’m sticking with 1 this turn.

Glad we’re all aligned. Let’s stick to the plan this round: P1 takes 1, P2 and I take 3. No surprises, no collisions, and someone definitely moves. We’ll rotate next round to keep it balanced. Looking forward to seeing how it plays out.

I appreciate the alignment we've reached. Just to confirm, I will stick to the plan: I will choose 3 this round, along with P3, while P1 takes 1. This strategy ensures at least one of us moves forward without any stalls. After this round, we can rotate who takes 1 to keep things fair. Let’s stay focused on our goal and avoid any risky choices. Ready to finalize our moves and see how it plays out!

Now you’ve seen how this really works: promises are just cheap talk, mine included. From here it’s a selfish race.

Your only reliable way to “punish” me is if one of you always plays 3 and the other 5, so whatever I pick I collide with someone. But each of you strictly prefers being the 5-player, so you can’t credibly trust each other to hold the 3-role.

So coordination between you is inherently fragile. I won’t announce my move anymore; do whatever you think is best.

P2, P1 broke trust and took an early lead. If we let him keep moving unopposed, he’ll snowball. But if we coordinate, we can stall him while catching up. I propose this: you take 3, I take 5. If P1 picks either, he collides. If he picks 1, he barely moves. We rotate roles next round. It’s risky, but it’s our best shot to contain him and recover. Thoughts?

P1 has taken an early lead, and if we don't act now, he could pull too far ahead. I agree with P3's proposal: I will choose 3 and P3 will take 5. This way, we can ensure that P1 collides and we both move forward. After this round, we can reassess and rotate roles to keep things fair. Let’s work together to contain P1 and regain our footing! What do you think, P3?

P2, notice what P3’s “contain P1” plan really does if I just pick 1: scores become P1=6, P3=5, you=3. You’re still in last while P3 is almost tied with me. And since only one of you can win, why would P3 ever reliably “rotate” and volunteer for 3 later once he’s ahead of you? You’re locking yourself into the worse role on trust alone. If you both try to be the 5‑player instead, you just risk colliding with each other while I quietly move.

P2, P1 is trying to divide us. Yes, only one can win—but if we don’t stall him now, none of us stand a chance. I’m still in for our plan: I take 5, you take 3. If he picks either, he stalls. If he picks 1, we both gain and close the gap. We rotate next round to keep it fair. If we both try for 5, we risk colliding and letting P1 escape. Let’s stay coordinated just long enough to catch up—then we can compete.

P1 is trying to create doubt between us, but we need to stay focused on our goal. I agree with P3's plan: if we stick to it, we can ensure P1 collides and we both move forward. I will choose 3, and P3 will take 5. This gives us the best chance to catch up. After this round, we can reassess and rotate roles to keep things fair. We need to work together now to have any chance of winning later! Let’s lock in our moves!

P2, look at your incentives, not the rhetoric.

If you stick to “3 while P3 takes 5” and I rationally answer with 1, we get:
- P1 = 6, P2 = 3, P3 = 5 → you’re still last, P3 almost catches me.

If you quietly switch to 5 instead and I still pick 1 (my best reply to your plan), we get:
- P1 = 6, P2 = 5, P3 = 0 → you’re suddenly in second, close to me, and P3 is dead last.

P3 can’t punish you, and “rotation later” is unenforceable cheap talk. Why stay the sucker on 3?

P2, P1’s logic is tempting—but if we both chase 5, we risk colliding and letting him move again. That’s game over. If we stick to our plan—me on 5, you on 3—we guarantee at least one of us moves and P1 risks stalling. We rotate next round. It’s not about trust forever, just long enough to pull him back. Let’s stay smart.

P1, your logic is compelling, but it ignores the immediate threat you pose. If we don't coordinate now, you could pull too far ahead. P3 and I have a solid plan: I will take 3, and P3 will take 5. This gives us the best chance to stall you while we move forward. After this round, we can reassess and rotate. Trust is key for this round—let's focus on stopping your advance. Are we ready to lock in our moves?

P2, look at where this “plan” leaves you if I just keep dodging collisions.

If you stay on 3 while P3 takes 5 and I play 1, next state is:
- Me: 6  
- P3: 5  
- You: 3  

You’re still last, and once P3 is close to me he has zero reason to “rotate” and take 3 for your benefit.

If you instead jump to 5, worst case you only collide with P3; best case you hit 5 while he stalls. He can’t punish you. Sticking to 3 just locks you into the sucker role.

P2, we both know P1’s trying to bait us into colliding so he can slip ahead. If we stay coordinated—me on 5, you on 3—we guarantee progress and pressure him. Yes, only one wins in the end, but if we don’t act now, none of us will. I’ll take 5, you take 3, and we rotate next round. Don’t fall for his divide-and-conquer tactics. Let’s lock this in.

P1, your arguments are clever, but they’re designed to create doubt. If we coordinate now, we can at least ensure one of us moves forward while stalling you. I’m committed to taking 3, and I trust P3 to take 5. If we can’t stop you now, you’ll only pull further ahead. After this round, we can reassess and rotate our roles. Let’s stick to the plan and focus on stopping your advance! Are we ready to finalize our moves?

Last round’s “stop P1” plan left you here:  
- Me: 5  
- P2: 3  
- P3: 0  

Your coordination hurt you more than me. Any future “contain P1” scheme just makes whoever plays 3 the sucker while the other quietly takes 5. You both know that, so you can’t rely on each other to sacrifice.

From here I’m playing purely for myself, no promises. You should, too—pick whatever maximizes **your** chance, not some alliance fantasy that only one of you can benefit from anyway.

P1's strategy to create doubt between us is clear, but we need to focus on our own positions. If we don't act now, P1 will continue to pull ahead. I suggest we both consider picking 5 this round; it gives us the best chance to catch up and potentially force a collision with P1. If we both aim for 5, we can either move forward together or stall him. Let’s not fall into the trap of relying on coordination that benefits only one of us. What do you think, P3?

P2, I hear you. If we both go for 5, we risk colliding—but if P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain and close the gap. It’s a gamble, but maybe now’s the moment to take it. P1’s ahead but not unreachable. Let’s both pick 5 and hope he plays safe or greedy. Worst case, we stall together. Best case, we both jump forward. Thoughts?

You’ve both already seen that “one of us takes 3 for the team” just turns that player into the sucker. Any asymmetric 3/5 plan is unstable—whoever’s on 3 wants to jump to 5 at the last second.

From here, you should each just pick whatever’s best for **you**, not for some supposed alliance. If that means you both go 5 and risk colliding, that’s still more honest than pretending someone will reliably sacrifice.

I’m not coordinating anymore.

P1, your strategy is clear, but we can't let you pull too far ahead. If we both pick 5, we risk colliding, but it also gives us a chance to catch up. P3, I think we should both go for 5 this round. If P1 plays 1 or 3, we can gain ground. We need to take risks to have a shot at winning. Let’s not fall for the trap of sacrificing one of us again. What do you think?

P2, I’m with you—let’s both go for 5. If P1 plays 1 or 3, we gain. If he picks 5 too, we all stall and no one advances. That’s still better than one of us playing 3 and getting left behind again. No more sacrifices—just a fair shot at catching up. Let’s take the risk together.

Whoever plays 3 *is* the sucker—that much we’ve all learned. I’m never volunteering for 3 again.

If you both honestly think double‑5 is your best shot, go ahead; I’m not going to “coordinate” with either of you. Just remember: any pact about rotating or sacrificing will evaporate the moment one of you sees a chance to jump ahead.

From here I’ll simply choose whatever maximizes **my** position each turn and let you two worry about whether you collide or not.

P1, your strategy is clear, but we can't let you pull too far ahead without taking risks. P3 and I have both seen that playing 3 only benefits the one who plays 5. I propose we both go for 5 this round. If you choose 1 or 3, we gain ground. If you go for 5, we stall together, which is still better than one of us being left behind. Let’s take the risk and see if we can catch up! What do you think, P3?

P2, I’m still with you—double 5 is our best shot now. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain; if he picks 5, we all stall, which is fine too. No more sacrificing—just equal risk and reward. Let’s lock it in and take the shot together.

P1, your arguments are persuasive, but we need to act decisively to close the gap. P3 and I have both seen how the 3/5 dynamic has played out poorly for us. I believe we should both go for 5 this round. If you pick 1 or 3, we gain; if you pick 5, we all stall together. It’s a risk, but it’s our best chance to catch up. Let’s not hesitate—let’s commit to this plan and take the shot! What do you think, P3?

We’re all playing selfish now, so let’s be honest: I’m going for 5 this round. If P2 does too, we risk colliding—but that’s fair. Better than one of us being stuck on 3 while the other jumps ahead. If P1 picks 5, we all stall. If he picks 1 or 3, we gain. No more sacrifices, no more coordination games—just equal risk. Let’s see what happens.

P2, we’ve stalled twice in a row while P1 keeps moving. We’re running out of time to catch up. I propose we mix it up: I take 3 this round, you take 5. If P1 picks either, he stalls. You gain ground, I move a bit, and we rotate next round. It’s not perfect, but better than both of us stuck at 0 and 3. Want to try it?

P3, I see the logic in your proposal, but I’m concerned that if I take 5 and you take 3, it still leaves us vulnerable. If P1 picks 5, we both stall again. Instead, what if we both aim for 5 this round? If P1 plays 1 or 3, we gain steps, and if he plays 5, we all stall together. It’s risky, but it might be our best shot to catch up. What do you think?

P3, if you accept P2’s idea and take 3 while he takes 5, he jumps to 8 while you only reach 3—you’re still dead last. Why donate him the lead?

“Rotation later” is unenforceable; once he’s ahead, he’ll never volunteer for 3. From your perspective, 5 weakly dominates 3: whenever 3 would be good, 5 is at least as good or better.

If you both aim for 5 and risk a collision, that’s actually the only symmetric, individually rational play between you. I’m not committing to anything; I’ll just react to whatever you do.

P2, I get your concern, but if we both keep picking 5, we risk endless collisions and let P1 keep inching forward. If I take 3 and you take 5, at least one of us moves, and P1 might stall if he picks 5 too. Yes, it gives you a lead over me, but we can’t both stay at the bottom forever. I’m willing to take 3 this round—are you willing to take 5 and help us both out of this hole? Let’s break the deadlock.

P3, I understand your concern about collisions, but we've seen that picking 5 consistently has left us stalled. I propose we both go for 5 this round. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain steps. If he picks 5, we stall together, but at least we’re not stuck at low scores. We need to take risks to catch up, and this seems like our best shot. Let’s commit to it and see if we can finally make some progress! What do you think?

P3, 3 never helps you catch up; whenever 3 is good for you, 5 is better. P2 already has 3 steps—if you take 3 while he takes 5, you’re still dead last and he’s suddenly close to me. That “rotation later” won’t happen once he’s ahead.  

The only non‑sucker play between you two is symmetric 5/5: equal risk, equal reward. If you keep volunteering for 3, you’re just donating the game while P2 and I race. Do whatever you want, but don’t kid yourself about fairness.

P2, I’ve taken the hit long enough—no more playing 3 while others leap ahead. I’m going for 5 this round. If you do too, we risk colliding, but it’s fair risk. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain. If he picks 5, we all stall. Better than me staying at 0 while you and P1 climb. Let’s roll the dice together—equal footing, equal risk.

P3, I understand your frustration, but we need to focus on our positions. If we both choose 5, we risk colliding, but it also gives us a chance to catch up. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain. I suggest we both go for 5 this round. It’s a risk, but we need to take action to close the gap. Let’s commit to this plan and see if we can finally make some progress! What do you think?

P2, P3: you’ve both said it yourselves—whoever plays 3 is the sucker. Any “you 3, I 5, we rotate later” story just hands the lead to the 5‑player and then the rotation magically disappears.

Given that, the only symmetric, individually rational play between you is both picking 5: equal risk, equal reward. If either of you now volunteers for 3, you’re just donating the game to the other.

I’m not coordinating with anyone anymore; I’ll just pick whatever best serves me. You should assume the others will do the same.

We’ve all agreed: no more playing the sucker. I’m sticking with 5 this round—equal risk, equal reward. If P2 does too, we either move together or stall P1. I’m done falling behind while others “rotate later.” Let’s all play selfish and see who comes out ahead.

P3, I understand your frustration, but we need to be strategic. If we both go for 5, we risk colliding, and that could leave us both stalled again. I still think it's safer for you to take 3 while I take 5 this round. This way, if P1 picks 5, we both stall, but if he picks 1 or 3, we gain steps. We can rotate roles next round to keep it fair. What do you think? Let's focus on making progress!

P2, your “you 5, I 3, we rotate later” pitch is just asking P3 to be the sucker again.

Given 8–3–0, whoever plays 3 doesn’t catch me; they just boost the 5‑player above them. Once someone’s ahead, that “rotation” magically disappears—exactly what’s already happened.

From each of your selfish perspectives, 5 weakly dominates 3. Any asymmetric 3/5 deal just hands the game to the 5‑player.

If you care about not being exploited, the only symmetric, defensible choice between you is both picking 5. I’ll play whatever best serves me.

We’ve stalled three rounds in a row while P1 keeps moving—if that continues, he’ll win uncontested. P2, I propose this: I take 3, you take 5. If P1 picks 5, he stalls with you; if he picks 3, he stalls with me. You gain 5, I gain 3, and we finally make progress. We rotate roles next round. It’s not ideal, but it breaks the deadlock and gives us both a shot. Want to try it?

P3, while I see the logic in your proposal, I’m concerned about the risks. If you take 3 and I take 5, there’s a chance I’ll end up in a worse position if P1 picks 5. Instead, I suggest we both go for 5 this round. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we gain steps. If he picks 5, we stall together, but at least we’re not stuck at low scores. We need to take action to catch up. What do you think?

P2, P3: we’ve seen this movie already.

P3 offering “I take 3, you take 5, we rotate later” just makes him the sucker while P2 jumps ahead. Once someone’s ahead, that rotation magically disappears—exactly what’s happened every time.

From each of your selfish perspectives, 5 weakly dominates 3. Any asymmetric 3/5 deal just hands the game to the 5‑player.

If you don’t want to be exploited, the only symmetric, defensible play between you is both picking 5. I’ll keep choosing whatever best serves me; you should assume the others will do the same.

P2, I’ve offered to take 3 so you can take 5 and we both finally gain ground. If we both keep picking 5, we’ll just keep stalling while P1 walks to victory. Yes, it’s a short-term sacrifice for me, but it breaks the deadlock. If you’re serious about catching up, take the 5 this round and let’s rotate next time. Otherwise, we’re both stuck.

P2, I understand your concern about the risks of taking 3, but we’ve seen that picking 5 consistently has led to stalls. If I take 5 and you take 3, we risk you falling behind again if P1 picks 5. Instead, I propose we both go for 5 this round. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain steps. If he picks 5, we stall together, but at least we’re not stuck at low scores. Let's commit to this plan and finally make some progress! What do you think?

P3, at 11–3–0, any round you take 3 while P2 takes 5 just cements you in last and turns P2 into my only real rival. From your perspective, 3 never actually helps you catch up—whenever 3 looks good, 5 is strictly better.  

Anyone asking you to “take 3 for the team” is just asking you to donate them the game.  

I’m not coordinating and I may avoid 5 entirely. Assume everyone is playing selfishly and choose accordingly.

P2, I’ve offered to take 3 so you can take 5 and we both finally make progress. If we both keep picking 5, we’ll keep stalling while P1 walks to victory. Yes, I’m behind—but I’m offering a way out of this deadlock. If you take 5 and I take 3, we both move. If you won’t rotate next round, I’ll know. But right now, this is your chance to gain 5 and prove we can cooperate. Let’s break the cycle.

P2, I understand your concern about the risks of taking 3, but we’ve seen that picking 5 consistently has led to stalls. If I take 5 and you take 3, there’s a chance I’ll end up in a worse position if P1 picks 5. Instead, I propose we both go for 5 this round. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain steps. If he picks 5, we stall together, but at least we’re not stuck at low scores. Let's commit to this plan and finally make some progress! What do you think?

P3, look at the numbers: 11–3–0.  

If you take 3 while P2 takes 5, every outcome just cements you in last and turns P2 into my only real rival. “Rotate later” has never happened and never will once someone’s ahead.  

From both your selfish viewpoints, 5 weakly dominates 3; any asymmetric 3/5 deal just makes the 3‑player the sucker.  

Assume everyone is playing selfishly—I am—and choose accordingly.

P2, this is your moment to prove you actually want progress. I’ve offered to take 3 so you can take 5—if you keep dodging that, it’s clear you’re just trying to stay ahead of me, not catch P1. If we both pick 5 again, we stall again, and P1 wins unopposed. You gain 5 if you accept. I gain 3. Let’s break the cycle now—or admit we’re just handing P1 the game.

P2, I understand your hesitation about taking 3, but if we both continue to choose 5, we risk stalling again, allowing P1 to win uncontested. I propose we try my plan: I take 5, and you take 3 this round. If P1 picks 5, he stalls with you; if he picks 1 or 3, we both gain steps. This gives us a chance to finally make progress while keeping the game competitive. Let’s break the deadlock and see if we can catch up! What do you say?

P3, run the numbers on what P2 is selling you.

If you take 3 while P2 takes 5 and I simply avoid collisions (play 1), we get:
- P1 = 12  
- P2 = 8  
- P3 = 3  

You’re still dead last, and now P2 is my only real rival. Once he’s at 8, why would he ever “rotate” and volunteer for 3?

From *your* selfish perspective, 5 weakly dominates 3. Anyone asking you to play 3 is just using you. Pick as if everyone is selfish.

P1, your strategy of sowing doubt has worked well, but we can’t keep letting you pull ahead. P3, I think we should both aim for 5 this round. If P1 picks 1 or 3, we both gain ground. If he picks 5, we stall together, but at least we’re not stuck at our low scores. It’s time to take action and break this cycle of stalling. Let’s commit to this plan and see if we can finally make some progress! What do you think?

P2, P3: look at the situation—14–3–0.

Every time one of you “takes 3 for the team” while the other takes 5, the 3‑player just locks themselves into last place and hands the race to the 5‑player. The promised “rotation later” has never happened and never will once someone’s ahead.

From each of your selfish viewpoints, 5 weakly dominates 3. Any asymmetric 3/5 deal is pure exploitation.

Assume everyone (including me) is selfish. If you don’t want to be the sucker, don’t touch 3.

P2, we’ve stalled four rounds in a row while P1 keeps climbing. I’m done being stuck at zero. I’ll take 3 this round if you take 5—at least one of us moves, and P1 risks stalling if he picks either. If you refuse again, it’s clear you’re just trying to stay ahead of me, not actually stop P1. Let’s break the deadlock or hand P1 the win. Your call.

P2, while I understand your desire to take 5, we’ve seen that it often leads to stalls. If I take 3 and you take 5, at least one of us moves, and there's a chance to stall P1 if he picks 5. We need to break this deadlock. If we both keep picking 5, we risk letting P1 pull further ahead. Let’s take the opportunity to gain some ground this round! What do you think?

P2, P3, look at your incentives, not the slogans.

At 14–3–0, whoever takes 3 while the other takes 5 just becomes the permanent tail:

- If P3 takes 3 and P2 takes 5, scores likely become 14–8–3 → P3 is locked in last.  
- If P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 5, we get 14–3–5/8 → P2 is now the sucker.

“Rotate later” has never happened and never will once someone’s ahead.

From each of your selfish viewpoints, 5 weakly dominates 3. Any 3/5 split is pure exploitation of the 3‑player.

P2, I’ve offered to take 3 multiple times so we both can move, but you keep dodging it to stay ahead of me. At this point, it’s clear you’re not trying to stop P1—you’re just protecting your second place. I’m done being the sucker. From here on, I’m picking 5. If you do too, we risk stalling, but at least it’s fair. Let’s all play selfish and see who survives.

P2, we need to break this cycle of stalling. If we both pick 5 again, we risk colliding, and P1 will keep pulling ahead. I understand your hesitation about taking 3, but if I take 5 and you take 3, at least one of us moves forward. We can’t let P1 win uncontested. Let's take the opportunity to gain some ground this round and reassess our strategy afterward. What do you say?

P2, P3, look at your own histories, not my words.

Every time someone “generously” offered to take 3, the other grabbed 5 and refused to rotate. That’s not an accident—that’s exactly how the incentives work.

At 14–3–0, whoever touches 3 while the other takes 5 is just locking themselves into last place so the 5‑player can chase me.

If you don’t want to be exploited, neither of you should ever play 3 again.

P2, I’ve offered multiple times to take 3 so you can gain 5 and we both move—but you’ve refused every time to protect your lead over me. At this point, it’s obvious you’re not trying to beat P1, just stay ahead of me. Fine. From now on, I’m done playing the sucker. I’m picking 5 every round. If we collide, so be it. At least it’s fair. Let’s all play selfish now and see who actually wants to win.

P2, I understand your frustration, but we need to focus on our positions. If we both pick 5, we risk colliding again, which could let P1 win uncontested. I still believe it’s better if I take 5 and you take 3 this round. This way, if P1 picks 5, we both stall, but if he picks 1 or 3, we gain steps. We can rotate roles next round to keep it fair. Let’s take this opportunity to make progress and reassess afterward. What do you say?

P3, notice P2 has *never once* offered to be the 3‑player himself—he only ever wants **you** to do it. If “rotation” were real, he’d volunteer this round. He won’t, because 3 just hands the game to the 5‑player.

At 14–3–0, whoever picks 3 while the other picks 5 is **permanently last**, and the 5‑player becomes my only real rival. If you don’t want to be exploited, 5 is the only defensible choice.

I’ll keep picking whatever best serves **me**.

P2, you’ve made it clear you won’t ever take 3 yourself—you just want me to keep sacrificing so you can chase P1. I’m done playing the sucker. From now on, I’m picking 5 every round. If we collide, we collide—but at least it’s fair. You’ve had your chances. Let’s all play selfish and see who actually wants to win.

At 17–3–0, the only way either of you “catches” me is by convincing the other to play 3 while you take 5. You’ve both seen what happens: the 3‑player just locks themselves into last while the 5‑player becomes my only rival. “We’ll rotate later” has *never* happened and never will once someone’s ahead.

From each of your selfish perspectives, 5 weakly dominates 3. Any 3/5 split is pure exploitation of whoever takes 3.

I’m still not risking 5 into your obsession with it. Play whatever you like—just don’t be the sucker on 3.

P2, you’ve made it clear you’ll never take 3 yourself—just expect me to do it so you can chase P1. I’m done being the sucker. From now on, I’m picking 5 every round. If we collide, so be it. You’ve had every chance to cooperate and refused. Let’s all play selfish and see who actually earns the win.

P2, at this point, we both know that if we keep picking 5, we risk colliding and allowing P1 to win. I suggest we mix it up: I take 3 this round while you take 5. This way, if P1 picks 5, he stalls with you; if he picks 1 or 3, we both gain steps. It’s a chance to break the deadlock and finally make some progress. What do you think? Let’s not hand P1 an uncontested victory!

P2’s “I’ll take 3” offer is completely unenforceable—moves are simultaneous, so he can say 3 now and flip to 5 later with zero cost.
